claims.claim: Returning citizens face significant barriers to housing due to their criminal records.
claims.quote: I couldn't rent anywhere. To save my life.

claims.claim: Formerly incarcerated individuals encounter challenges in securing employment related to their field of training.
claims.quote: I was part of the building trades in Huron Valley, so I figured I'd have a job with Habitat for Humanity, since they use Habitat for Humanity in prison. But when I came out, I asked, I applied for the job. They said I was a felon.

claims.claim: Organizations often do not recognize informal or non-traditional homelessness among returning citizens.
claims.quote: I tried to get help through different organizations. They told me I wasn't homeless. Well, that's not my address. I'm just sleeping on the couch.

claims.claim: Employment opportunities are scarce for returning citizens, particularly those not interested in factory jobs or low-wage work.
claims.quote: Besides Habitat for Humanity, I went looking. I really am not a factory person. The factory thing was not for me. The two, the, the two and few dollars at like McDonald's and stuff, that wasn't gonna help me.

claims.claim: Criminal records prevent returning citizens from accessing jobs even when they have relevant skills and training.
claims.quote: Because getting a job, job I got, got tired of saying, you know, you, you check the box, it's a wrap. You know, my name ain't felony 'cause I got a felony, you know?

claims.claim: Returning citizens often resort to informal work to make ends meet due to challenges in securing formal employment.
claims.quote: You know, learning how to drywall, helping people frame out stuff they need. Some carpenters, there was some paint on the wall, do some demo work. Anything that had to do with housing at that time to put my house still to get a couple of dollars. I was working under the table, but it made it happen.
